As frustration and violence over the extension of slavery grew in the 1840's, Van Buren ran for the presidency twice more from this house. He hoped to unite sectional interests but failed; ultimately so did the union.
Fresh air and beautiful scenes!
At the Kinderhook Dutch Reformed Cemetery on Albany Ave in the Village of Kinderhook the President, his wife Hannah, and his son are buried.
can't get here because of snow or other reasons?  No problem.  Check out the virtual tour of the President's beloved home.
Whether you want to visit as an individual or with a group, this is the place to do all your advance planning.

name: Mammoth Cave National Park
history: Mammoth Cave National Park preserves the cave system and a part of the Green River valley and hilly country of south central Kentucky. This is the world's longest known cave system, with more than 400 miles explored. Early guide Stephen Bishop called the cave a "grand, gloomy and peculiar place," but its vast chambers and complex labyrinths have earned its name - Mammoth.
A girl looks into the cave shadows, anticipating her cave tour.
A car entering past the park entrance sign reading "Mammoth Cave National Park"
Up-to-date maps of Mammoth Cave National Park
P.O. Box

name: Marsh - Billings - Rockefeller National Historical Park
history: Walk through one of Vermont's most beautiful landscapes, under the shade of sugar maples and 400-year-old hemlocks, across covered bridges and alongside rambling stone walls. This is a landscape of loss, recovery, and conservation. This is a story of stewardship, of people taking care of places - sharing an enduring connection to land and a sense of hope for the future.
Park opening weekends 10-4 from May 6. Please call 802-457-3368 x222 to schedule a Mansion tour. Full schedule starts Memorial Day Weekend.
Join our volunteer Phenology monitoring crew and learn to collect data in your own backyard.
Join the park’s ecologist and naturalist on this moderate 1.5 mile hike to look and listen for birds.
Spring is here! Join us for some spring service projects: Learn about phenology, help us get the trails ready, or work on the AT
Check out the Park (and partners) summer stewardship experiences for youth

name: Mississippi Delta National Heritage Area
history:
The Blues, Welty, Wright, Williams, Civil War and Civil Rights, The Great Flood, Bogues and Bayous, Plantations, The Great Migration, Rock ‘n’ Roll, Soul Food, King Cotton, The River, Precision Agriculture, Catfish, Gospel, Immigrants' Stories, Highway 61, Segregation, Integration, Share Cropping, Freedom Songs, Freedom Summer, Folk Tales, Swamp Forests, Hunting Clubs, and surprisingly, hot tamale 
Mississippi Hills NHA one of 12 NHAs in the Southeast.

name: Lower East Side Tenement Museum National Historic Site
history:
The heart of the museum is a historic tenement, home to an estimated 7,000 people from over 20 nations between 1863 and 1935. The tenement’s cramped living spaces, the lives of past residents and the history of the Lower East Side, contribute to its representation of the immigrant experience. Throughout the year, programs such as walking tours and readings are offered. 
Learn what to do and where to go when you visit!

name: Manzanar National Historic Site
history:
In 1942, the United States government ordered more than 110,000 men, women, and children to leave their homes and detained them in remote, military-style camps. Manzanar War Relocation Center was one of ten camps where Japanese American citizens and resident Japanese aliens were incarcerated during World War II. 
Gardens and ponds at Manzanar are symbolic and speak of hope, resistance and beauty while the barracks represent daily life in confinement.

name: Manassas National Battlefield Park
history:
On July 21, 1861, two armies clashed for the first time on the fields overlooking Bull Run. Heavy fighting swept away any notion of a quick war. In August 1862, Union and Confederate armies converged for a second time on the plains of Manassas. The Confederates won a solid victory bringing them to the height of their power. 
Learn more about the First Battle of Manassas (Bull Run) - July 21, 1861.
Learn more about the Confederate victory at the Second Battle of Manassas (Bull Run) - August 28-30, 1862.

name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
history:
Longfellow House - Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site preserves the home of Henry W. Longfellow, one of the world’s foremost 19th century poets. The house also served as headquarters for General George Washington during the Siege of Boston, July 1775 - April 1776. In addition to its rich history, the site offers unique opportunities to explore 19th century literature and arts. 
Walk through the rooms where Henry Longfellow crafted American masterpieces and George Washington commanded the Continental Army.

name: Maggie L Walker National Historic Site
history:
Maggie Lena Walker devoted her life to civil rights advancement, economic empowerment, and educational opportunities for Jim Crow-era African Americans and women. As a bank president, newspaper editor, and fraternal leader, Walker served as an inspiration of pride and progress. Today, Walker’s home is preserved as a tribute to her enduring legacy of vision, courage, and determination. 
Maggie L. Walker and Independent Order of St. Luke staff members in front of St. Luke Hall, 1917

name: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
history: Little Rock Central High School is recognized for the role it played in the desegregation of public schools in the United States.  The nine African-American students' persistence in attending the formerly all-white Central High School was the most prominent national example of the implementation of the May 17, 1954 Supreme Court decision Brown v. Board of Education.
This park is your classroom from Elementary to College; we're firm believers in life long learning.
In commemoration of the 60th Anniversary of the desegregation of Central High School, we're partnering with AETN to host a film competition!
The only way into Central High School is with a Ranger. Find out how to schedule one today.
Good news, Fourth Graders! The National Park Service is offering Fourth Graders and their family free access to your Public Lands!
Field Trip Reimbursement Grants, loan materials, lesson plans, field trip opportunities and professional development opportunities.

name: Lower Delaware National Wild and Scenic River
history:
The largest free-flowing river in the eastern United States, the Delaware River runs past forests, farmlands, and villages, and it also links some of the most densely populated regions in America.
In 2000, the National Wild and Scenic River System incorporated key segments of the lower Delaware River to form this unit of the National Park System. 
The lower Delaware River has never been long off the nation's mind; it lies between 2 of the great colonial cities of the nation: NY and Phi

name: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
history: ---Lyndon Baines Johnson

Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park tells the story of our 36th President beginning with his ancestors until his final resting place on his beloved LBJ Ranch. This entire "circle of life" gives the visitor a unique perspective into one of America's most noteworthy citizens by providing the most complete picture of any American president.
While a ranger-guided tour of the Texas White House is a highlight of any visit to the LBJ Ranch, there is much to see along the way.
LBJ National Historical Park is looking for youths between the ages of 15 to 18 to participate in the YCC program from June 12 to August 4.
Movies Under the Stars for 2016 celebrates the 50th Anniversary of "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" with a showing on June 3.

name: Lowell National Historical Park
history: Discover the continuing revolution. Lowell’s water-powered textile mills catapulted the nation – including immigrant families and early female factory workers – into an uncertain new industrial era. Nearly 200 years later, the changes that began here still reverberate in our shifting global economy. Explore Lowell, a living monument to the dynamic human story of the Industrial Revolution.
Film Screening and Discussion of "Browsing Through Birke's," highlighting the story behind a Lowell landmark business. April 25 at 6:30 p.m.
Join us at Lowell National Historical Park and many other community partners for a week of free fun family programs, April 15-23.
In honor of National Park Week, admission to the Boott Cotton Mills Museum will be free on the weekends- April 15 & 16, and 22 & 23.
Free Drop-in Family Programs on Saturdays. Next program- storytelling with the Kindred Project on April 29, 1-4 p.m. at the Visitor Center.
Looking for dreamers, doers, movers, and makers to "mill around" with us and explore history, science, and nature. Sign up by May 31.
Celebrating 25 years of the Tsongas Industrial History Center throughout the year. Check our events calendar and join in the celebration!
Lots going on this Spring in Lowell. Check out our hours, special programs and events, and plan your visit today!

name: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
history: Explore the timeless rainforests and majestic coastal vistas. Discover the rich heritage of the native people. Unfold the dramatic stories of America's most famous explorers. The park encompasses sites along the Columbia River and the Pacific Coast. Follow in the footsteps of the explorers and have an adventure in history.
Chat with a ranger at Fort Clatsop, kayak through a wetland, or enjoy the sunset over the Columbia River, Find Your Park at Lewis and Clark.

Survive and Thrive in Nature!
Get Outdoors at Nature Survival and Nature Adventure Camps
Apply to work with park staff on projects like trail building and re-vegetation,   invasive plant removal and wetland restoration!
A monthly conversation about nature and culture, the second Thursday of the month, October through May at Fort George Brewery, Astoria, Ore.
On the third Sunday, September through May at 1 p.m., this speaker series is an opportunity to meet scholars, authors, and artists.
Salty Talks speaker series is presented at 6:30 p.m. every second Wednesday of the month, October through May at SALT Pub, Ilwaco, Wash.

name: Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument
history: This area memorializes the U.S. Army's 7th Cavalry and the Sioux and Cheyenne in one of the Indian's last armed efforts to preserve their way of life. Here on June 25 and 26 of 1876, 263 soldiers, including Lt. Col. George A. Custer and attached personnel of the U.S. Army, died fighting several thousand Lakota, and Cheyenne warriors.
Learn more about Little Bighorn's Museum and Archival Collections.
Explore the Historic Photos from the Museum and Archives Collections.
From the Visitor Center drive the tour road to retrace the steps of the Battle through multiple audio tour stops and exhibits.
Pretty Eagle Catholic School students plant trees that were donated by the Friends of the Little Bighorn Battlefield.

name: Little River Canyon National Preserve
history: Little River is unique because it flows for most of its length atop Lookout Mountain in northeast Alabama. Forested uplands, waterfalls, canyon rims and bluffs, pools, boulders, and sandstone cliffs offer settings for a variety of recreational activities. Natural resources and cultural heritage come together to tell the story of the Preserve, a special place in the Southern Appalachians.
Help your child explore their world. Show them the beauty nature has to offer and teach them how to protect parks for future generations.
Enjoy the spectacular views of Little River Canyon from the Overlooks.
Little River Falls located on AL Hwy 35 is pretty in any season.
Black Snakes and other animals call the park home. Please respect them.
Little River Falls in the Winter Season

name: Maine Acadian Culture
history: Maine Acadians share beliefs and experiences tying them to a common religion, languages, and history. The St. John River, land, and family are essential to their culture. The National Park Service supports the Maine Acadian Heritage Council, an association of historical societies, cultural clubs, towns, and museums that work together to support Maine Acadian culture in the St. John Valley.
Visit museums, historical societies, and more in this scenic area of northern Maine.
Explore some of the historical and cultural sites that preserve the heritage of Maine Acadians.
Discover the history and cultural heritage of Maine's Upper Saint John Valley.
P.O. Box

name: Lincoln Memorial
history:
"In this temple, as in the hearts of the people for whom he saved the Union, the memory of Abraham Lincoln is enshrined forever." Beneath these words, the 16th President of the United States sits immortalized in marble as an enduring symbol of unity, strength, and wisdom. 
History of the Lincoln Memorial

name: Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area
history: In 1941 the Grand Coulee Dam was built on the Columbia River as part of the Columbia River Basin project, creating a 130-mile long lake. Named for President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area provides opportunities for boating, fishing, swimming, camping, canoeing, hunting and visiting historic Fort Spokane and St. Paul's Mission.
Things to do and see while you explore the park!
Come enjoy the great outdoors with us!
All of our information about boating can be found here!
Come fish with us all throughout Lake Roosevelt!
Take a walk through history with us!
All information about Hunting in the park can be found here.

name: Lincoln Home National Historic Site
history:
Abraham Lincoln believed in the ideal that everyone in America should have the opportunity to improve his/her economic and social condition.  Lincoln’s life was the embodiment of that idea.  We know him as the sixteenth president but he was also a spouse, parent, and neighbor who experienced the same hopes, dreams, and challenges of life that are still experienced by many people. 
Visit the only home that Abraham Lincoln ever owned.
Lincoln Home NHS offers a wide range of accessibility options.

name: Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial
history:
Abraham Lincoln grew from youth to manhood on this southern Indiana soil.  Many character and moral traits of one of the world's most respected leaders was formed and nurtured here.  Explore Lincoln's boyhood and learn about the boy who would one day become the leader of our nation. 
The homestead is typical of the of the 1820s.  It is located on four of the original 160 acres owned by Thomas Lincoln. 
A bronze casting of sill logs and fireplace hearthstones symbolizes a cabin that the Lincolns began building in 1829.
The Memorial Building is Indiana's effort to memorialize Abraham Lincoln.  Completed in 1943, it was built in the spirit of Indiana in 1816.

name: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail
history:
Between May 1804 and September 1806, 31 men, one woman, and a baby traveled from the plains of the Midwest to the shores of the Pacific Ocean. They called themselves the Corps of Discovery. In their search for a water route to the Pacific Ocean, they opened a window into the west for the young United States. 
Use the maps page to plan your adventures along the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.
 Take a look back at the Centennial year with the 2016 Annual Report.

name: Lava Beds National Monument
history: Lava Beds National Monument is a land of turmoil, both geological and historical. Over the last half-million years, volcanic eruptions on the Medicine Lake shield volcano have created a rugged landscape dotted with diverse volcanic features. More than 700 caves, Native American rock art sites, historic battlefields and campsites, and a high desert wilderness experience await you!
As lava flowed through the park and cooled it left behind caves waiting to be  explored! Visit the visitor center before caving.
During the Modoc War of 1872-1873, a small band of Modocs used their knowledge of the homeland's terrain to their tactical advantage.
Learn all about the many species of bats that can be found in our National Parks.
Calling all 4th graders! Get your Every Kid in a Park pass and visit the hundreds of natural, cultural, and historical NPS sites for FREE!
Learn more about what you can do to stay safe during your visit.

name: Lassen Volcanic National Park
history: Lassen Volcanic National Park is home to steaming fumaroles, meadows freckled with wildflowers, clear mountain lakes, and numerous volcanoes. Jagged peaks tell the story of its eruptive past while hot water continues to shape the land. Lassen Volcanic offers opportunities to discover the wonder and mysteries of volcanoes and hot water for visitors willing to explore the undiscovered.
Discover all there is to see and do in your national parks. Entrance is free to all park sites April 15-16 and 22-23.
Road crews began clearing the 30-mile park highway on April 10. It can take up to two months before the highway opens to through traffic.
There are plenty of ways to enjoy winter at Lassen. Winter conditions can exist November through June or July.
Check road conditions, snow depths, the weather forecast, and webcams.
Ensure your visit to Lassen in winter is a safe and enjoyable one.
A helpful resource in planning a summertime visit is the summer edition of the park newspaper.
Explore science in the park and plan your summer visit with information in the 2017 summer/fall newspaper.
Discover the art of nature photography and plein air watercolor painting or join a guided hike with a hiking book author.
Learn to make Klamath region national parks your climate change classroom in this teacher development workshop July 23-August 4, 2017.

name: Lake Mead National Recreation Area
history: Boat, hike, cycle, camp and fish at America’s most diverse national recreation area. With striking landscapes and brilliant blue waters, this year-round playground spreads across 1.5 million acres of mountains, canyons, valleys and two vast lakes. See the Hoover Dam from the waters of Lake Mead or Lake Mohave, or find solitude in one of the park's nine wilderness areas.
The Surface Project is an exciting online resource that brings the stories and science within Lake Mead and Lake Mohave to the surface.
With more than 290 square miles of water surface, you can be sure to find a favorite spot to catch the big one.
Find destinations to visit at Lake Mead National Recreation Area
Camping locations and information
Historical artifacts and photos from the archives of Lake Mead NRA
Visit a town once underwater at Lake Mead National Recreation Area
Visit one of our marinas at Lake Mead NRA.
Directions & Transportation, Maps
The scenic Colorado River flowing through Lake Mead NRA
There are several lodging locations at Lake Mead NRA
Discover the many marinas and coves at Lake Mead NRA

name: Klondike Gold Rush - Seattle Unit National Historical Park
history:
The Seattle unit of the Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park preserves the story of the stampede to the Yukon gold fields and Seattle's crucial role in this event. The headlines of a Seattle newspaper on July 17, 1897, Gold! Gold! Gold! Gold! ignited dreams of easy riches in the minds of thousands as word of a rich gold strike in northwestern Canada. A dream that would prove all but dream. 
You set the pace for your Klondike experience in Seattle.
A visit to Klondike-Seattle is like no other adventure.

name: Korean War Veterans Memorial
history:
Our nation honors her sons and daughters who answered the call to defend a country they never knew and a people they never met. 
Our nation honors her sons and daughters who answered the call to defend a country they never knew and a people they never met.

name: Lake Meredith National Recreation Area
history:
Within the dry and windswept high plains of the Texas Panhandle lies a hidden oasis, a welcoming haven where wildlife and humans find respite from the dry grasslands above. Through this plain, the Canadian River has cut dramatic 200-foot canyons, or breaks, where humans have eked out a living for over 13,000 years. Lake Meredith now occupies these hidden coves where early humans once roamed. 
Enjoy a pleasant stroll though a quiet river valley or a steep hike up to the top of a mesa.
Lake Meredith National Recreation Area offers a variety of campgrounds where you can enjoy the lake or get a bit off the beaten path.
Bring your boat and explore the lake!

name: Lake Clark National Park & Preserve
history: Lake Clark National Park is a land of stunning beauty where volcanoes steam, salmon run, bears forage, craggy mountains reflect in shimmering turquoise lakes, and local people and culture still depend on the land and water of their home.  Solitude is found around every bend in the river and shoulder of a mountain.  Venture into the park to become part of the wilderness.
Bring Lake Clark to your students by using one of our lesson plans in your classroom.
The newly published Proenneke journals describe life in the first few years after Twin Lakes became part of Lake Clark National Park.
After more than 15 years of continual study, the lives of Lake Clark's sockeye salmon are coming into focus.
Watch "A Day on the Lake Clark National Park Coastline," learn where to go see bears, & become familiar with bear viewing best practices.
Discover how different the lives of Lake Clark's coastal & interior brown bears really are and see what this means for you.

name: Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park
history: Headlines screamed "Gold!" The dream of a better life catapulted thousands of people to Alaska and the Yukon Territory. Their journey shaped them, and changed the people they encountered and the north forever. Today, the park remembers the trails, boomtowns, and stories of the Klondike Gold Rush.
Learn about the great human drama that was the mad dash to the far north known as the Klondike Gold Rush.
Plan your hike through the "meanest 33 miles in history."
Over 20 gold rush boom town buildings are part of the park today.  Explore the ones in Skagway's Historic District.
Join a ranger on one of our ranger guided tours and talks

name: Kobuk Valley National Park
history: Caribou, sand dunes, the Kobuk River, Onion Portage - just some of the facets of Kobuk Valley National Park. Half a million caribou migrate through, their tracks crisscrossing sculpted dunes. The Kobuk River is an ancient and current path for people and wildlife. For 9000 years, people came to Onion Portage to harvest caribou as they swam the river. Even today, that rich tradition continues.
Create a video postcard in Kobuk Valley National Park to celebrate the National Park Service's Centennial.
For 8,000 years, people have come to Onion Portage to hunt caribou. It is one of the most important archeological sites in the Arctic.
The Great Kobuk Sand Dunes are the largest active sand dunes in the Arctic.
Find out more about Kobuk Valley National Park in these blogs written by park rangers, researchers and pilots.
Kotzebue students get a real life look at what it means to be a field biologist in the wilderness of Kobuk Valley National Park.
Check out this week's Ranger Report, a short news report on natural resources, science and wildlife made by local Kotzebue students.

name: Knife River Indian Villages National Historic Site
history: Earthlodge people hunted bison and other game, but were in essence farmers living in villages along the Missouri and its tributaries. The site was a major Native American trade center for hundreds of years prior to becoming an important market place for fur traders after 1750.
Two children re enacting village life
Beaded Gloves in the Robinson Collection
Canoes during kids camp
Porcupine, linked to the parks nature informaiton
Earthlodge school program

name: Keweenaw National Historical Park
history: From 7,000 years ago to the 1900s people mined Keweenaw copper. Native peoples made copper into tools and trade items. Investors and immigrants arrived in the 1800s in a great mineral rush, developing thriving industries and cosmopolitan communities. Though the mines have since closed, their mark is still visible on the land and people.
Explore the Keweenaw's rich copper mining and cultural heritage through twenty-one diverse sites.
Learn details about the Copper TRACES Field Day this May, and how to register your fourth grade class.
Find all of your High School Local History Smackdown 2017 information here.
Volunteer opportunities are available at the Keweenaw Heritage Sites and Keweenaw National Historical Park.
Explore a timeline of Michigan copper mining from prehistory to the present.

name: LBJ Memorial Grove on the Potomac
history:
From this distance the seat of national power appears pristine across the river, so President Johnson came here often when he needed to escape from the stresses of building a Great Society. After he died, his wife chose this place for his memorial. A landscape of serpentine paths, white pines, a granite monolith, and an open meadow honors his legacy of social justice and conservation legislation. 
Keep our park clean! These interns and volunteers came out to clean up the park!

name: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park
history: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park is a 2,965 acre National Battlefield that preserves a Civil War battleground of the Atlanta Campaign. Opposing forces maneuvered and fought here from June 19, 1864 until July 2, 1864. Although most famous as a Civil War battlefield, Kennesaw Mountain has a much richer story.
Illinois Monument
Stay Connected with Kennesaw Mountain NBP.
"State of the Park" Report.
Trading Cards for Kids

name: Kings Mountain National Military Park
history:
Thomas Jefferson called it "The turn of the tide of success." The battle of Kings Mountain, fought October 7th, 1780, was an important American victory during the Revolutionary War. The battle was the first major patriot victory to occur after the British invasion of Charleston, SC in May 1780. The park preserves the site of this important battle.
Kings Mountain National Military Park has a variety of upcoming events.

name: Kenai Fjords National Park
history: At the edge of the Kenai Peninsula lies a land where the ice age lingers. Nearly 40 glaciers flow from the Harding Icefield, Kenai Fjords' crowning feature. Wildlife thrives in icy waters and lush forests around this vast expanse of ice. Native Alutiiq relied on these resources to nurture a life entwined with the sea. Today, shrinking glaciers bear witness to the effects of our changing climate.
Join a park ranger for a short walk, interpretive talk, or a day hike and learn more about your park.
Boat tours depart Seward's small boat harbor daily during the summer months, making it easy to travel deeper into the park.
Exit Glacier, the only part of the park accessible by road, offers short trails, viewpoints, and a nature center.
As a playground for kayakers, stand-up paddleboarders, and campers, Bear Glacier Lagoon draws a variety of visitors to Kenai Fjords.
Completing the strenuous Harding Icefield Trail represents quite an accomplishment. The 8.2-mile round trip provides a spectacular day hike.
Kayaking in Kenai Fjords can be an exciting way to explore the fjords, see glaciers, and view wildlife.

name: Katmai National Park & Preserve
history: Katmai National Monument was established in 1918 to protect the volcanically devastated region surrounding Mount Katmai and the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes. Today, Katmai National Park and Preserve remains an active volcanic landscape, but it also protects 9,000 years of human history as well as important habitat for salmon and thousands of brown bears.
Get started planning your Katmai adventure.
Watch live streaming footage of Brooks River's brown bears.
Read why Brooks Camp is Katmai's most popular destination.
Share with others why you think Katmai and national parks are important.
Read the latest news, information, and opinions from park staff.
Find an authorized commercial operator.

name: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
history:
Spread across a wild landscape offering spectacular views of Mount Katahdin, Katahdin Woods and Waters invites discovery of its rivers, streams, woods, flora, fauna, geology, and the night skies that have attracted humans for millennia. 
Experience Katahdin on skis, on snowmobiles, on ice, and more.
The national monument offers solitude and opportunities to experience the woods, rivers, trails, and scenic vistas.

name: Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail
history: "¡Vayan Subiendo!"("Everyone mount up!") was the rousing call from Juan Bautista de Anza. In 1775-76, he led some 240 men, women, and children on an epic journey to establish the first non-Native settlement at San Francisco Bay. Today, the 1,200-mile Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail connects history, culture, and outdoor recreation from Nogales, Arizona, to the San Francisco Bay Area.
A diverse group of 30 migrant families scratched their way across the frontier of New Spain, and carved their way into American history.
These historic and cultural sites host heritage events and exhibits about the Anza Trail in southern Arizona.
Historic, cultural, and natural sites reveal the legacy of California's Spanish colonial era.
Click here to see and download a map of the Juan Bautista de Anza expedition.
Stretch your legs on some of the quintessential Anza Trail hikes.
Annual heritage events commemorate the epic journey of the Anza Expedition of 1775-76.
Anza Trail guides ride the Amtrak Coast Starlight between San Jose & Santa Barbara. See this year's schedule and learn how to become a guide
Click to find out what's going on in and around the trail.
Use the Anza Trail as a teaching tool in your classroom or community.
Learn more about what we're doing and share your images and experiences on the trail.
Click here to go to our Flickr page and see images from events and more!
Be sure to follow us on Twitter to learn more about the Juan Bautista de Anza NHT.

name: Kalaupapa National Historical Park
history: When Hansen's disease (leprosy) was introduced to the Hawaiian Islands, King Kamehameha V banished all afflicted to the isolated Kalaupapa peninsula on the north shore of Molokai.

Since 1866, more than 8000 people, mostly Hawaiians, have died at Kalaupapa. Once a prison, Kalaupapa is now refuge for the few remaining residents who are now cured, but were forced to live their lives in isolation.
Learn how to plan your visit to Kalaupapa and experience the most from your visit.
Learn about the breadth and depth of historic resources at the park, including landscapes, historic buildings, museum collections, and more.
Learn about the many threatened and endangered species at Kalaupapa, and what the park is doing to protect them.
The National Park Service is celebrating 100 years in 2016.  See how we are celebrating at Kalaupapa.
P.O. Box

name: Joshua Tree National Park
history: Two distinct desert ecosystems, the Mojave and the Colorado, come together in Joshua Tree National Park. A fascinating variety of plants and animals make their homes in a land sculpted by strong winds and occasional torrents of rain. Dark night skies, a rich cultural history, and surreal geologic features add to the wonder of this vast wilderness in southern California. Come explore for yourself.
Sleep under the stars at one of Joshua Tree's nine developed campgrounds.
Where to go, what to do, and what you need to know for your Joshua Tree adventure.
Activities with pets are very limited in Joshua Tree. Learn how to make the most out of your visit and keep your furry friend safe.
You can help protect Joshua Tree's wildlife by following a few simple guidelines.
Dagger-like leaves? Sprawling, zig-zaggy branches? The Joshua tree looks like it belongs in a Dr. Seuss book.

name: Kenilworth Park & Aquatic Gardens
history: In an age old dance wind, water, and land combine here.  Sparkling in the sun on a breezy day, this natural area of Anacostia Park has origins in a 1926 act of Congress to preserve the forests, water quality, and recreation value of the waterways of Washington, DC.  The park reflects the policies that affect rivers and wetlands.  Come, join the dance.
Discover lotus and lily flowers, wildlife, and more!
Come celebrate with us, through one of a kind historic bird walks and fun for the whole family, International Migratory Bird Day!
The park hosts a festival every summer to celebrate the spectacular blooming of water lilies and lotuses.
Interested in volunteering? Volunteering is a great way to give back to the community and have fun.
Join a Park Ranger as we explore Kenilworth Aquatic Gardens and Marsh to find resident birds and arriving spring migrants from the tropics.
Visit us on social media before, during, and after your visit to Kenilworth.

name: Johnstown Flood National Memorial
history:
The South Fork dam failed on Friday, May 31, 1889 and unleashed 20,000,000 tons of water that devastated Johnstown, PA.  The flood killed 2,209 people but it brought the nation and the world together to aid the "Johnstown sufferers."  The story of the Johnstown Flood reminds us all, "...that we must leave nothing undone for the preservation and protection of our brother men." 
Sitting along Lake Conemaugh, this building was the main structure of the South Fork Fishing and Hunting Club. 
The Lake View Visitor Center has two floors of exhibits and the park film, "Black Friday."

name: John Muir National Historic Site
history: John Muir played many roles in his life, all of which helped him succeed in his role as an advocate for Nature. As America’s most famous naturalist and conservationist, Muir fought to protect the wild places he loved, places we can still visit today. Muir’s writings convinced the U.S. government to protect Yosemite, Sequoia, Grand Canyon and Mt. Rainier as national parks.
John Muir worked, raised a family and wrote in his Martinez, California home.
Join us on Saturday, April 22nd at the John Muir National Historic Site. Free admission, booths, entertainment and more...Click for info.
Enjoy one of our Camp Fire programs at the John Muir NHS. Singing, stories and more. Click for dates and time.
Join a National Park ranger for an interpretive walk on Mount Wanda, under the night sky.
Join National Park Service Rangers for a stargazing adventure
Can't make it to the park? Watch the official park film, shown in our digital theater, about the life of John Muir.
Learn more about John Muir, his family and his closest friends.
Nature and Conservation. Places of importance in John Muir's life.
Click here to learn about the ways you can enjoy the John Muir National Historic Site.
Here are some answers to commonly asked questions.
The Martinez Adobe, an historic home and exhibit, is part of the Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail.
Muir was also an inventor of unusual things.
Learn more about the nature experience in our park. From wildlife to native plants.
"Check In", share you photos, and "Like" us on Facebook! :-)
We now have an Instagram account! Share your images from the park. #johnmuirnationalhistoricsite
Check out our Twitter feed.

name: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
history:
As a boy, JFK’s parents never expected he would grow up to be President. Yet in his birthplace home he learned values that inspired a life in public service. His mother, Rose Kennedy, recreated her family’s first home to share her memories of those early years with visitors. In 2017, the centennial of JFK’s birth, we commemorate not only his early life, but the ideas and principles he left behind. 
John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site opens for the season on May 19, 2017. Until then, tours are offered by appointment only.
Calling all kids: The site will be open on April 22, 2017 to celebrate Junior Ranger Day with a brand new Jr Ranger book!
We're celebrating the centennial of JFK's birth in 2017. Join us for special events throughout the year.

name: John H. Chafee Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor
history: The Blackstone River runs from Worcester, MA to Providence, RI. Its waters powered the Slater Mill in Pawtucket, RI, America's first successful cotton spinning mill. This creative spark began the nation's transformation from Farm to Factory. Today, the Blackstone River Valley is a special type of National Park - a living landscape containing thousands of natural and historic treasures.
The Heritage Corridor has lesson plans ready to use in your classroom right now.
Blackstone Valley 101 is a free, interactive on-line learning program that gives an overview of the history and heritage of the valley.
Twenty-four episodes of our award-winning public access cable program "Along the Blackstone" are now available for you to watch and download
Click here to visit the website of the Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park
Click to see the website of the nonprofit management entity that oversees the Heritage Corridor

name: James A Garfield National Historic Site
history: A front porch can serve many purposes. For some, a place to enjoy the breeze on a warm summer night. For others, a perch from which to keep eyes on what's happening in their neighborhood. In 1880, James Garfield used his front porch as a platform to greet thousands of well-wishers during his presidential campaign. Today, the porch serves as a gateway to the story of the Garfield family.
We are open for an Egg Roll just like the White House! Come and participate in games, activities, egg hunts and egg roll for kids!
Please click here for an up-to-date list of our programs and special events.
Enjoy lunch at Skye Bistro in Mentor while enriching your knowledge on interesting topics presented by Garfield staff and volunteers.
Bring lunch and join us at Mentor Library the second Wednesday of each month for discussions on Civil War era topics. Programs are at noon.
4th graders can earn an Every Kid in Park pass, admitting them and their family into national parks around the country for FREE!
Teachers can book a FREE program for 4th graders, including a ranger classroom visit and Garfield site field trip. Click here for more!
Book a FREE program about national parks for 4th graders in your community!
Calling all reenactors to participate at the  Civil War Encampment July 15-16, 2017.

name: Jewel Cave National Monument
history:
Immerse yourself within the third longest cave in the world. With over 180 miles of mapped and surveyed passages, this underground wilderness appeals to human curiosity. Its splendor is revealed through fragile formations and glimpses of brilliant color. Its maze of passages lure explorers, and its scientific wealth remains a mystery. This resource is truly a jewel in the National Park Service. 
What kind of cave tour experience do you desire?  Park Rangers offer four different types of cave tours ranging from easy to strenuous.
Guided nature hikes occur daily during the summer months.  The hikes provide recreation and a chance to learn about the pine forest.
Challenge and provoke your kids to learn more about the monument through the Junior Ranger Program, for kids ages 5 - 12.

name: Jimmy Carter National Historic Site
history:
Few U.S. Presidents have had such close ties with where they were born and raised. The rural southern culture of Plains, Georgia, that revolves around farming, church and school, had a large influence in molding the character and in shaping the political policies of the 39th President of the United States. 
President Carter and Mrs. Carter at the visitor center
This link takes the user to the page where the Presidential Site Song Challenge videos are hosted. 
The project brings scientists, naturalists, and volunteers together to identify as many species as possible in a short time frame

name: Kaloko-Honokōhau National Historical Park
history: To survive in a hot and arid environment the native Hawaiians (kanaka maoli) used ancient fishing skills, including the building of fishponds, and the knowledge of the location of precious fresh water (wai) that flows into the many brackish pools throughout the park. The spirit of the people (poe) and the knowledge of the elders (kupuna) created a tradition of respect and reverence for this area.
See the park's calendar for cultural events
View programs and upcoming events!
Studies related to water quality/quantity in the park are ongoing.
Educational Programs offered at the park
Learn about Plant Communities, Benthic, Marine Fish, Climate, Anchialine Pools, Groundwater, & Water Quality.
Listing of events for Kaloko-Honokohau in 2016!

name: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument
history:
Colorful rock formations at John Day Fossil Beds preserve a world class record of plant and animal evolution, changing climate, and past ecosystems that span over 40 million years.  Exhibits and a working lab at the Thomas Condon Paleontology Center as well as scenic drives and hikes at all three units allow visitors to explore the prehistoric past of Oregon and see science in action. 
Learn about North America's and the world's past from one of the most complete fossil records on the planet.
Travel back into the distant past in North America, to the wilds of volcanic Central Oregon.
The National Park Service turns 100 this year, and we are celebrating with special events.

name: Isle Royale National Park
history: Explore a rugged, isolated island, far from the sights and sounds of civilization. Surrounded by Lake Superior, Isle Royale offers unparalleled solitude and adventures for backpackers, hikers, boaters, kayakers, canoeists and scuba divers. Here, amid stunning scenic beauty, you'll find opportunities for reflection and discovery, and make memories that last a lifetime.
New for 2017, Isle Royale now charges a daily $7 per person entrance fee. All Federal Recreation Passes waive this fee. Get details!
"Frog loggers" record amphibian sounds around Isle Royale. Learn more about the Great Lakes Inventory & Monitoring Network.
Use #isleroyalenps on Instagram for a chance for your island photo to be featured.
The Greenstone newspaper is the one-stop trip planning guide for visiting Isle Royale.
What park improvement projects have your fees funded? Check out a project list by year.

name: Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore
history: Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore hugs 15 miles of the southern shore of Lake Michigan and has much to offer. Whether you enjoy scouting for rare species of birds or flying kites on the sandy beach, the national lakeshore's 15,000 acres will continually enchant you.  Hikers will enjoy 50 miles of trails over rugged dunes, mysterious wetlands, sunny prairies, meandering rivers and peaceful forests.
Saturday, April 29 at 10 am - 3 pm, celebrate Earth Day at this family-oriented event.
April 9 and 29, join staff and map lovers for an introduction to orienteering at the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore.
April 15-23, celebrate National Park Week by taking part in various programs scheduled throughout the national lakeshore.
Singing Sands Newspaper
Outdoor Activities Galore! October 6-8, 2017, enjoy events throughout Porter, La Porte, and Lake counties.
Celebrate the migration of bird life through the Indiana Dunes region from May 4-7, 2017 at the third-annual Indiana Dunes Birding Festival.
Upcoming special events and activities
Explore a new world of possibilities in learning about Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore.

name: Independence National Historical Park
history: Goods, ideas, and people intermingled in early Philadelphia.  In this diverse city, a new republic was born.  The Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution were both debated and signed inside Independence Hall.  Nearby sits the Liberty Bell, an international symbol of liberty.
See this international symbol of liberty.  No tickets are needed.
Entrance to Independence Hall is by tour only.Tickets are required March through December. No tickets are required in January and February.
Explore a state-of-the-art museum honoring Philadelphia's own Benjamin Franklin.
Enjoy performances, ceremonies, and more.  Are you in?
Looking for the history of Independence Hall or the story of the Liberty Bell?  We've got that!

name: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail
history:
"At the end of the last Ice Age, some 12,000 to 17,000 years ago, a series of cataclysmic floods occurred in what is now the northwest region of the United States, leaving a lasting mark of dramatic and distinguishing features on the landscape of parts of the States of Montana, Idaho, Washington and Oregon." 
Public Law 111-11, March 30, 2009 
Some scientists think that over 40 floods once flowed again and again across the region.

name: Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site
history: The squeaky wooden floor greets your entry into the oldest operating trading post on the Navajo Nation.  When your eyes adjust to the dim light in the "bullpen" you find you’ve just entered a mercantile.  Hubbell's has been serving Ganado selling groceries, grain, hardware, horse tack, coffee and Native American Art since 1878.
Discover Hubbell Trading Post NHS, where history is made every day.
This event will be held in Gallup in May and provides an opportunity for local artisans to sell their arts and crafts
Roadwork on State Route 264 may cause delays for visitors to Hubbell Trading Post NHS
The fee has increased for Tours of the Hubbell Home

name: Ice Age National Scenic Trail
history:
A mere 15,000 years ago during the Ice Age, much of North America lay under a huge glacier. Mammoths, saber tooth cats and cave lions roamed the earth! Some of the best evidence of this glacier is found in Wisconsin such as the state’s many lakes, river valleys, gently rolling hills, and ridges. The nearly 1,200 mile Ice Age National Scenic Trail, established in 1980, traces the glacier's edge. 
Enjoying a winter hike on the trail.
TRAIL SAFE! is a unique safety training program designed specifically for NPS trail volunteers, but is useful to everyone!

name: Iñupiat Heritage Center
history: On the rooftop of the world, the Iñupiat Heritage Center in Barrow, Alaska, tells the story of the Iñupiat people. They have thrived for thousands of years in one of the harshest climates on Earth, hunting the bowhead, or "Agviq." In the 19th century, these lonely seas swarmed with commercial whalemen from New England, who also sought the bowhead for its valuable baleen and blubber.

name: Horseshoe Bend National Military Park
history:
On 27 March 1814, Major General Andrew Jackson ‘s army of 3,300 men attacked Chief Menawa’s 1,000 Red Stick Creek warriors fortified in a horseshoe shaped bend of the Tallapoosa River.  Over 800 Red Sticks died that day.  The battle ended the Creek War, resulted in a land cession of 23,000,000 acres to the United States and created a national hero of Andrew Jackson. 
Horseshoe Bend NMP welcomed area students for education days. Click for more information.
Horseshoe Bend offers unique opportunities for volunteers from helping with visitors to firing traditional flint lock weapons, learn more!

name: Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site
history:
Hopewell Furnace showcases an early American industrial landscape from natural resource extraction to enlightened conservation. Operating from 1771-1883, Hopewell and other "iron plantations" laid the foundation for the transformation of the United States into an industrial giant. The park's 848 acres and historic structures illustrate the business, technology and lifestyle of our growing nation. 
Brief list of activities visitors can use to plan their visit to Hopewell Furnace.

name: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
history: In Jean Lafitte's day, silver and gold filled a pirate's treasure chest, but today's treasures are people, places, and memories. Discover New Orleans’ rich cultural mix. Learn Cajun traditions from people who live them. Watch an alligator bask on a bayou’s bank. Walk in the footsteps of the men who fought at 1815’s Battle of New Orleans. Follow the link to discover the treasure of Jean Lafitte.
Explore Louisiana's wild wetlands---swamp, marsh, bayous, alligators, birds---just 17 miles from New Orleans.
Follow the footsteps of the troops who fought 1815's Battle of New Orleans  and find out how the American victory changed the world.
Discover how three centuries of cultural exchange have created one of America's most distinctive cities.
Old traditions, new homes: through exhibits, programs, and boat tours, discover how Canada's Acadians became Louisiana's Cajuns.
Celebrate the Cajun way of life with music,dancing, cooking demonstrations, and more.
Big fun on the bayou: it's all about music, Cajun French, boat tours, and life in Louisiana's wetlands.
In April, take a tour or lend a hand at Chalmette National Cemetery
#FindYourkPark / #EncuentraTuParque at Jean Lafitte April 15-23!
Breath, stretch, and smile on Park Rx Day (Saturday, April 23) with a yoga flash mob at New Orleans' Audubon Park.
Calling all kids---explore life in south Louisiana through Jean Lafitte summer day camps and discover local nature, culture, and more.
Entergy proposes to rebuild/replace an existing transmission line that crosses the Barataria Preserve. Learn more and share your comments.
Commercial photography or filming? A special event like a wedding or a bike race? Research? Hunting? Learn about special permits.

name: Hopewell Culture National Historical Park
history: Earthen mounds and embankments forming huge geometric enclosures grace the landscape of the Ohio River Valley. These monumental structures were built by Native American hands almost 2,000 years ago. Hopewellian people gathered at these earthworks for feasts, funerals and rites of passage.  Come learn about these sacred spaces and reflect upon the lives of these American Indians.
The bid for World Heritage is picking up. Read the official submission and learn how you can help.
The 2017 Grassland Conversion Plan is now available to review and comment on. Comment period ends April 15th, 2017.
Help celebrate National Park Week by browsing through the special events we have planned here at the park.  There's something for everyone!
The park is a fantastic place to supplement classroom learning of early Native Americans.  Schedule a field trip with your students today!
Park rangers are available for in-class visits!  Supplement your prehistoric Ohio lessons with a prehistoric ranger program.
Parks as Classrooms is a unique way to utilize the nation's public lands for educational tools. Speaker info, lesson plans and more await.
Learn how you and your family can all earn your own park Junior Ranger badge while learning cool stuff!
The limited edition Centennial Jr. Ranger badges are now available at the park!  Ask a ranger how you can earn your limited edition badge.
4th graders can now earn their free parks pass!  This special pass waives entry fees to thousands of federal sites in the United States.
Make the Mound City Group visitor center your first stop when visiting the park. Explore the museum and view the award-winning intro film.
Visiting the park from out of town?  Looking for some good eats and convenient, affordable lodging?  Look no further, click here & discover.
The park hosts several annual events on-site throughout the year.  Find out what event is next and all the info about it as well.
Learn about the historic and prehistoric history of this incredible park.  Over 2,000 years of history await you at Hopewell Culture NHP.
On the 100th anniversary of the National Park Service, Hopewell Culture NHP celebrates the grand opening of its 5th of 6 sites.
Hear and see the compelling story of two park employees and how they found their park at Hopewell Culture NHP.
Park video productions and assorted multimedia can be found here. All videos are downloadable as are multimedia presentations.
Looking for a rewarding and memorable experience? Become a Volunteer In Park (VIP) and help us fulfill our mission.
We can't do it alone. Therefore, the park is fortunate to have lasting affiliations with many partners who help us in our mission.
Directions to the park's visitor center and the two other accessible sites can be found here with a link to customized directions.
Find out what condition the roads around the park are in before you get in your car during severe weather.
Information on regulations for firearms, unmanned aircraft systems (UAS, Drones) and Permits can be found here.
A listing of Seasonal and Permanant staff at the park with emails.

name: Homestead National Monument of America
history: With the promise of Free Land, the Homestead Act of 1862 enticed millions to cultivate the frontier. Families, immigrants, women, and freed slaves flooded 10 percent of the nation’s land to chase their American Dream. American Indian cultures and natural environments gave way to diverse settlement, agricultural success, and industrial advancement—building our nation and changing the land forever.
Arizona, Illinois, Indiana, Nevada, and Ohio Homestead Records have been digitized and are available online.  Over 30 Million Pages!
This year, YOU are invited to celebrate all that America’s National Parks have to offer. Free Admission to all Parks April 15-23.
Check back often for program updates about Homesteading and the Total Eclipse of 2017.
Locate Barn Quilts across SE Nebraska with this map. Many participants learned to paint quilt blocks during workshops at Homestead NM.
Fourth graders can earn a free pass to visit public lands with their families! Complete a fun activity to get your pass and start exploring!

Apply for a plot in Homestead's Community Garden this spring!
The garden is located at the Heritage Center near the Palmer-Epard Cabin.
A view of the oldest restored tallgrass prairie in the National Park Service located at Homestead National Monument of America near Beatrice

name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
history: "All that is within me cries out to go back to my home on the Hudson River" FDR

This quote captures FDR's connection to Springwood, the estate that he loved & the place he considered home. The first US Presidential Library was started by FDR here. Visit the Home of FDR and Presidential Library & Museum to learn about the only President elected to four terms.
Calendar of Events for the Roosevelt-Vanderbilt National Historic Site
There's so much to see and do in Hyde Park, NY, and the National Park Service and Metro-North Railroad make it easy for you.
Roosevelt-Vanderbilt  National Historic Site
Are you a U.S. Veteran interested in working for the National Park Service at Roosevelt-Vanderbilt National Historic Site?
FDR Home Garden
Exhibit (located at Vanderbilt Mansion Visitor Center) - Celebrating FDR's Conservation Legacy

name: Hohokam Pima National Monument
history: This content is currently unavailable.
Please try back later.

name: Hovenweep National Monument
history:
Once home to over 2,500 people, Hovenweep includes six prehistoric villages built between A.D. 1200 and 1300. Explore a variety of structures, including multistory towers perched on canyon rims and balanced on boulders. The construction and attention to detail will leave you marveling at the skill and motivation of the builders. 
Our Artist in the Parks program connects local artists to the inspiring landscapes of national parks and monuments in southeast Utah.
Read more about things to do and places to go at Hovenweep.
Canyon Country Outdoor Education leads local school groups on field trips throughout the area.

name: Hawai'i Volcanoes National Park
history: Volcanoes are monuments to Earth's origin, evidence that its primordial forces are still at work. During a volcanic eruption, we are reminded that our planet is an ever-changing environment whose basic processes are beyond human control. As much as we have altered the face of the Earth to suit our needs, we can only stand in awe before the power of an eruption.

Video of the lava lake activity in Halema‘uma‘u Crater on March 6, 2017 in the morning. This is a zoomed video from the observation deck at Jaggar Museum, which is about a mile from the eruption site. For the best quality, click on the HD button (available when video is playing) and select Broadband (HD).
Updates on Current Conditions
Visiting the Jaggar Museum is one of many things to do at the park.
Informative and educational videos and photographs with the option to view on-line or download for off-line use
Save the date for the 37th Annual Hawaiian Cultural Festival & BioBlitz at Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park - July 8, 2017!
Please help prevent the spread of this terrible disease
Finding Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park
There are two campgrounds in Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park
Volcano House is just a short walk across Crater Rim Drive from the Kilauea Visitor Center.
Passes may be purchased on-line
Park entrance station -  Kīlauea Visitor Center is a Short Distance Ahead on the Right
Find closure and advisory information as well as drone/unmanned aircraft  and other park policies

name: Hot Springs National Park
history: Water. That's what first attracted people, and they have been coming here ever since to use these soothing thermal waters to heal and relax. Rich and poor alike came for the baths, and a thriving city built up around the hot springs. Together nicknamed "The American Spa," Hot Springs National Park today surrounds the north end of the city of Hot Springs, Arkansas. Come discover it for yourself.
You are invited to celebrate National Park Week, and all that Hot Springs National Park has to offer.
These pools are 1 of 3 location where you can see and touch the 143 degree (F) thermal water.
Volunteers are an essential part of park operations at Hot Springs National Park.
Explore Bathhouse Row, scenic drives, trails, and camping in the park.

name: Honouliuli National Monument
history:
Although not yet open to the public, Honouliuli National Monument (NM) will tell the history of internment, martial law, and the experience of prisoners of war in Hawai‘i during World War II. Honouliuli NM will be a place to reflect on wartime experiences and recommit ourselves to the pursuit of freedom and justice. 
Information and updates on Honouliuli National Monument planning efforts
Although not yet open to the public, there are many ways to learn about the history of Honouliuli National Monument 
President Obama announced the creation of Honouliuli National Monument by presidential proclamation.

name: Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park
history: Harriet Tubman was a deeply spiritual woman who lived her ideals and dedicated her life to freedom. She is the Underground Railroad’s best known conductor and before the Civil War repeatedly risked her life to guide nearly 70 enslaved people north to new lives of freedom. This new national historical park preserves the same landscapes that Tubman used to carry herself and others away from slavery.
Explore Harriet Tubman's World
Walk through our exhibits, or take the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad Scenic Byway!
Research and articles that detail Tubman's life and legacy.
Learn more about the Underground Railroad and the network of people and sites who aided freedom seekers.
Classroom lesson plans, field trip materials, and other resources to use our landscapes and stories with your students!
Learn about the park's founding, partnerships, and mission.

name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
history:
Walk in the steps of Captain John Smith and Pocahontas where a successful English colonization of North America began.  Despite early struggles to survive, the 1607 settlement evolved into a prosperous colony.  As the colony expanded, the Virginia Indians were pushed out of their homeland.  In 1619, the arrival of Africans was recorded, marking the origin of slavery in English North America. 
Tour Loop Road Entrance
Historic Jamestowne Visitor Center in Winter
Check this site for road closures.

name: Herbert Hoover National Historic Site
history: Born in a two-room cottage, Herbert Hoover could have been any small town boy. Orphaned at age nine, he left West Branch, never to live here again. The landscape and buildings of the early years remain, however, to tell how family, faith, education, and hard work opened a world of opportunity— even the presidency of the United States— to a child of simple beginnings.
Values learned in his hometown of rural West Branch guided Herbert Hoover throughout his life of service to the nation and the world.
President Hoover's birthplace and the park's other historic features symbolize American ideals as Herbert Hoover saw them and lived them.
Part of the National Archives, the presidential library allows people to explore the legacy of Herbert Hoover's presidency.
Use the mobile app on your visit to West Branch, Iowa to discover the places and people that shaped the early life of the 31st President.
An activity booklet helps kids learn more about Herbert Hoover National Historic Site during their visit.
Kids can visit historic places and learn about Herbert Hoover on a class field trip.
Reserve picnic shelters, book field trips, and apply for special use permits.
Help protect the park by knowing the rules before you visit.
Artists-in-residence share their inspirations with visitors as they creatively interpret the historic site.

name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
history: President Harry S Truman took America from its traditional isolationism into the age of international involvement. Despite his power, he never forgot where he came from. Today, visitors can experience the surroundings Truman knew as a young man of modest ambition through his political career and final years as a former president.
Take a guided tour of the Truman Home for an in-depth view of the personal and family life of the 33rd President of the United States
Harry S Truman NHS preserves  over 50,000 artifacts related to the Truman family.  Click below to see a selection of objects.
Get connected with Facebook, twitter & more.  Experience the park in an entirely new way.
Visit the family farm in Grandview where Harry lived for eleven years.  Grounds open daily. Audio tours available on site.
Over the past 29 years, this program has continued to preserve important information passed down about the Truman family’s home life.
A photographic tour of the second floor of the Truman Home is available. Due to the fragile structure of the house the upstairs is not open.
See the home of Harry's cousins to learn more about the courtship of Harry & Bess and life in the Truman neighborhood. Open every day.
Home to Bess's brothers George and Frank Wallace, these homes behind the Truman Home show a close family bond. Homes not open to public.

name: Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area
history:
Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area stretches from New York City to Albany. The area resources exhibit the roles of freedom and dignity in the valley's history, and the historical and contemporary role of commerce. Revolutionary War stories, famous residences, scenic parks and gardens, and landscape interpretations all contribute to the Hudson Valley's beauty and wealth of resources. 
Learn what to do and where to go where you visit!

name: Haleakalā National Park
history: This special place vibrates with stories of ancient and modern Hawaiian culture and protects the bond between the land and its people. The park also cares for endangered species, some of which exist nowhere else. Come visit this special place - renew your spirit amid stark volcanic landscapes and sub-tropical rain forest with an unforgettable hike through the backcountry.
Reserve your spot and get more information about the sunrise reservation system at Haleakalā National Park.
Make your visit more enjoyable, know before you go.
View the latest conditions of Haleakalā crater via our summit webcam. Watch park related videos
Find lesson plans and plan your field trip as you use Haleakalā as your classroom!
The Hawaiian Islands are the most remote major island group on Earth with unique plants and animals.
Become a Haleakalā Junior Ranger! Learn more about the park's habitat, the Hawaiian alphabet and more!
Park map and hiking map. Chinese, French, German, Korean, and Spanish handouts.
We need your kōkua (help) to deter a plant disease from reaching native forests on Maui.

name: Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument
history:
Did you know horses evolved in North America?  The Hagerman Horse, Equus simplicidens, was the first true horse (but its bones resemble Grevy’s zebra bones). It's the park's most famous fossil but we have over two hundred different species.  From saber-toothed cat, mastodon, bear, camel, and ground sloth, to much smaller animals, the scientific study of Pliocene fossils is the key to Hagerman.  
Hagerman horse fossil skeletons were excavated in the early 1930s by the Smithsonian Institution. These skeletons were traded worldwide.
Lontra weiri lived at Hagerman over 3.8 million years ago and is the oldest known ancestor of today’s American river otters.
Learn about Sibiloi National Park in Kenya. Sister Park to Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument.
If you are between the ages of 6 and 100+ years old, we invite you to become a Hagerman Fossil Beds Junior Ranger.

name: Harriet Tubman National Historical Park
history:
Harriet Tubman was guided by a deep faith and devotion to family, freedom, and community. After emancipating herself and members of her family, she moved them from Ontario, Canada to Auburn, New York in 1859. Central New York was a center for progressive thought, abolition, and women’s suffrage where Tubman continued to fight for human rights and dignity until she died in 1913. 
Harriet Tubman emancipated herself and escaped to freedom at age 27, then helped dozens of slaves find freedom.
Learn more about the historic sites that make up Harriet Tubman National Historical Park and how to visit.

name: Gulf Islands National Seashore
history: What is it that entices people to the sea?  Poet John Masefield wrote, “I must go down to the seas again, for the call of the running tide is a wild call and a clear call that may not be denied.”  Millions of visitors are drawn to the islands in the northern Gulf of Mexico for the white sandy beaches, the aquamarine waters, a boat ride, a camping spot, a tour of an old fort, or a place to fish.
Recreation, exploration, and education...you can do it all at Gulf Islands National Seashore.
Whether you're at the park for a couple hours or a couple of weeks, there are activities for everyone.
There are 12 unique places to visit and explore at Gulf Islands National Seashore
Download the Fort Pickens Self-guiding Tour on your mobile device.
Download the Fort Barrancas Self-guiding Tour to your mobile device and start your tour.
Download the Advanced Redoubt Self-guiding Tour to your mobile device.

name: Hampton National Historic Site
history: The Hampton estate was created and evolved through the actions of enslaved African Americans, European indentured servants and the Ridgely family within a nation struggling to define its own concept of freedom.
Dressed in period attire, Park Ranger Anokwale will guide visitors through the authentic slave quarters and overseer’s house.
Juneteenth celebrates African American freedom and achievement, while encouraging continuous self-development and respect for all cultures
Come celebrate Mother’s Day in a special way with all that Hampton National Historic Site has to offer.
Embark on an in depth self-guided tour of Hampton mansion, grounds, gardens and out buildings any day of the week on your personal device.

name: Guilford Courthouse National Military Park
history: "I never saw such fighting since God made me. The Americans fought like demons."
-Lt. General Charles, Earl Cornwallis

The largest battle of the Revolutionary War's Southern Campaign was fought at the small North Carolina backcountry hamlet of Guilford Courthouse. The battle proved to be a turning point for British military operations in the Revolutionary War.
Learn about the history, commemoration, and preservation of Battle of Guilford Courthouse.
The Revolution belongs to you. Find your park, find the colonial backcountry, and find history March 18-19th.
Help America’s first preserved Revolutionary War battlefield celebrate its 100th birthday!

name: Harmony Hall
history:
The 18th century Harmony Hall mansion is located on a 62.5-acre open pasture land estate along the Potomac River.  This estate was purchased by the National Park Service in 1966, to preserve southern Maryland cultural heritage. Surrounded by a rich landscape, it offers visitors many chances to connect with Colonial History. The park also home to the remains of the Want Water House and canal. 
Harmony Hall has one of the oldest structures in Prince Georges County within its boundaries...Want Water.

name: Guadalupe Mountains National Park
history: Guadalupe Mountains National Park is the world's premier example of a fossil reef from the Permian Era.  The park is known for its extensive hiking and backpacking opportunities in one of the nation's most pristine wilderness areas.  Birding, history, and many other opportunities to learn and have fun await visitors in this hidden gem of West Texas.
This year we invite youths ages 6-17 to share their favorite nature memory with us!
Check the latest weather conditions at the park.
Learn about primitive camping at the Pine Springs and Dog Canyon campgrounds. Find information on tent and RV sites.
The park's calendar includes information on fee free days, evening programs and ranger guided hikes.

name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park
history: Ridge upon ridge of forest straddles the border between North Carolina and Tennessee in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. World renowned for its diversity of plant and animal life, the beauty of its ancient mountains, and the quality of its remnants of Southern Appalachian mountain culture, this is America's most visited national park.
Bears in the park are wild and their behavior can be unpredictable. Treat bear encounters with extreme caution!
Wildlife viewing, historic homes and churches, and beautiful mountain scenery make Cades Cove the most popular destination in the park.
From the earliest hepaticas in late winter to the last asters in late fall, blooming flowers can be found nearly year-round in the park.
Feel the cool spray of a waterfall. Camp under the stars. Explore a historic mill. There's plenty to see and do in the park!

name: Journey Through Hallowed Ground National Heritage Area
history: Learn what to do and where to go when you visit!

name: Harpers Ferry National Historical Park
history: A visit to this quaint, historic community, at the confluence of the Potomac and Shenandoah rivers, is like stepping into the past.  Stroll the picturesque streets, visit exhibits and museums, or hike our trails and battlefields. Spend a day or a weekend.  We have something for everyone, so come and discover Harpers Ferry!
Join the park's archeologist and other cultural resources staff for hikes, programs, and presentations throughout the year.
Join the park's natural resources staff for hikes and presentations about birds, plants, and other organisms that inhabit Harpers Ferry.
Join us in commemorating the 150th anniversary of the founding of Storer College. Special programs, music, and events are planned for 2017.
Check out the special events and ranger programs that Harpers Ferry NHP has to offer!
Hike one of the park's trails to enjoy history and nature while in the outdoors! Trail difficulty ranges from easy to strenuous.
Learn more about our historic trades workshops and register for one of these unique opportunities!

name: Great Falls Park
history: At Great Falls, the Potomac River builds up speed and force as it falls over a series of steep, jagged rocks and flows through the narrow Mather Gorge. The Patowmack Canal offers a glimpse into the early history of this country.  Great Falls Park has many opportunities to explore history and nature, all in a beautiful 800-acre park only 15 miles from the Nation's Capital.
Get an inside perspective of Great Falls Park, including real time images and video posts. Also find out about park news and future events.
Our younger visitors are often looking for fun ways to enjoy learning about our parks. Ask at the visitor center about our Jr Ranger books.
Great Falls is just one place to visit along George Washington Memorial parkway. Discover historic homes, carousels, nature and more.
Swimming and Wading are strictly prohibited at Great Falls Park due to the 30+ foot deep, deadly river currents.  Know before you go!

name: Gullah/Geechee Cultural Heritage Corridor
history:
Designated by Congress in 2006, the Gullah Geechee Cultural Heritage Corridor extends from Wilmington, North Carolina in the north to Jacksonville, Florida in the south. It is home to one of America's most unique cultures, a tradition first shaped by captive Africans brought to the southern United States from West Africa and continued in later generations by their descendents. 
Spanning the coast from North Carolina to Florida

name: Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site
history:
Wide open spaces, the hard-working cowboy, his spirited cow pony, and vast herds of cattle are among the strongest symbols of the American West. Once the headquarters of a 10 million acre cattle empire, Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site preserves these symbols and commemorates the role of cattlemen in American history. 
Interested in seeing a haying or branding demonstration? This is where you can find dates and times for special events.

name: Hamilton Grange National Memorial
history:
Alexander Hamilton created the tools for the success of the United States. From his humble beginnings as an orphan on the Caribbean island of Nevis, he became George Washington's right-hand man. Come visit Hamilton Grange and find out more about this controversial founder and the country home that he built on his Harlem estate. 
Hamilton Grange on the way to its new home in St. Nicholas Park.
National Parks of New York Harbor App

name: Grand Teton National Park
history: Rising above a scene rich with extraordinary wildlife, pristine lakes, and alpine terrain, the Teton Range stands monument to the people who fought to protect it. These are mountains of the imagination. Mountains that led to the creation of Grand Teton National Park where you can explore over two hundred miles of trails, float the Snake River or enjoy the serenity of this remarkable place.
Grand Teton has a lot to offer whatever your interests. Explore our Plan Your Visit pages to help with your trip planning.
On August 21, 2017 a solar eclipse will happen across America with the center crossing Grand Teton. Plan your viewing now!
Backpacking in the Teton Range is popular in summer. Reservations open Wednesday, January 4 at 8 am MST.
Changes are happening around South Jenny Lake! The multi-year Jenny Lake Renewal Project is well underway. Completion expected spring 2018.
Download our new app before you get here! Explore Grand Teton and discover places to visit, find a bite to eat, and a place to stay.
Grand Teton hosts a variety of special programs and events through out the year. Search our Events Calendar.

name: Grand Canyon National Park
history: Unique combinations of geologic color and erosional forms decorate a canyon that is 277 river miles (446km) long, up to 18 miles (29km) wide, and a mile (1.6km) deep. Grand Canyon overwhelms our senses through its immense size
The South Rim of the park is open all year
The North Rim of the park is closed for winter.
The North Rim reopens on May 15 for the 2017 Season
Park lodging books up well in advance, Make reservations as far ahead as possible. North Rim is closed for the winter - reopens May 15, 2017
Planning a visit in 2017? Campground reservations are recommended for Mather Campground on S. Rim and the N. Rim Campground (No hookups)
Backcountry camping, river trips, weddings, commercial tours, filming, scientific research, special events and activities.
Download and read our Trip Planner before you visit the park. Contains useful information and essential maps for both North and South Rims.
During spring break, summer and holidays, arrive by 9 am to beat the crowds and find good parking. Here are some additional tips:
On the South Rim, no need to drive around in traffic. Park your car and ride shuttle buses around the village and out to scenic overlooks.

name: Greenbelt Park
history: Just twelve miles from Washington, D.C., Greenbelt Park is located in suburban Greenbelt, Maryland.
The park features a 174 site campground with specific site reservations, nine miles of trails, and three picnic areas.
The campground is open all year round.
The campground is known for its affordability, safety, peaceful surroundings, and National Park Service hospitality.
Greenbelt Park offers 174 campground sites with hot showers and bathroom facilities. We offer site specific reservations year round.

Discover four different trails ranging from 1 mile to 5.3 miles.
Azalea 1.2, Dogwood 1.8, Blueberry 1.0 and the Perimeter 5.3 miles
Camp in the Urban Oasis of Greenbelt Park. There is a dedicated A loop for scouts and organized groups.
Greenbelt Park is offering programs for all ages.
Annual, Senior, Military, Access and Every Kid in a Park Passes are available at the Greenbelt Park Ranger Station.
The Holly and Laurel Picnic Areas are available for reservations from April 1 - September 30. Groups up to 200 people can be accommodated,
Join our team of volunteers on Saturday May 6. Help preserve the park for this and future generations by removing the invasive plants.
Enjoy the Outdoors and Make a difference on Saturday May 20!  Join the Greenbelt Park Trail Crew once a month to improve the trail system.
Your group, school, or company can make it a great day at Greenbelt Park with a stewardship project.

name: Great Sand Dunes National Park & Preserve
history: The tallest dunes in North America are the centerpiece in a diverse landscape of grasslands, wetlands, conifer and aspen forests, alpine lakes, and tundra. Experience this diversity through hiking, sand sledding, splashing in Medano Creek, wildlife watching, and more!
Things to do, current and forecast conditions, camping and lodging, and more...
Detailed Medano Creek conditions and forecast flow, flow graph, and what to expect month by month in an average year
Sand sledding, Medano Creek beach play, experiencing the night, hiking through forests, climbing to alpine lakes and peaks, and more...
Get the best weather forecasts for various elevations in the park and preserve, weather info for each season, and a live webcam view
Camping options and information, including developed campgrounds, 4WD vehicle camping, and backpacking

name: Golden Gate National Recreation Area
history: Experience a park so rich it supports 19 distinct ecosystems with over 2,000 plant and animal species. Go for a hike, enjoy a vista, have a picnic or learn about the centuries of overlapping history from California’s indigenous cultures, Spanish colonialism, the Mexican Republic, US military expansion and the growth of San Francisco. All of this and more awaits you, so get out and find your park.
A new way to Find Your Park
